weakness.name: CWE-1283
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1283: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

weakness.name: CWE-208
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.
In security-relevant contexts, even small variations in timing can be exploited by attackers to indirectly infer certain details about the product's internal operations. For example, in some cryptographic algorithms, attackers can use timing differences to infer certain properties about a private key, making the key easier to guess. Timing discrepancies effectively form a timing side channel.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-601
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect') A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks. An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance. Whether this issue poses a vulnerability will be subject to the intended behavior of the application. For example, a search engine might intentionally provide redirects to arbitrary URLs.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-912
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-912: Hidden Functionality The product contains functionality that is not documented, not part of the specification, and not accessible through an interface or command sequence that is obvious to the product's users or administrators. Hidden functionality can take many forms, such as intentionally malicious code, "Easter Eggs" that contain extraneous functionality such as games, developer-friendly shortcuts that reduce maintenance or support costs such as hard-coded accounts, etc. From a security perspective, even when the functionality is not intentionally malicious or damaging, it can increase the product's attack surface and expose additional weaknesses beyond what is already exposed by the intended functionality. Even if it is not easily accessible, the hidden functionality could be useful for attacks that modify the control flow of the application.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege to service accounts
countermeasure.desc:
Create one dedicated service account for each App Engine service or environment and attach only the IAM roles that the code truly needsnothing more, never Editor or Owner.

Implementation guidance

  1. Provision purpose-built accounts
    • Console IAM & Admin Service Accounts Create, give each account a descriptive name (e.g., sa-billing-api-prod).
    • Disable the default App Engine and Compute Engine service accounts if your workload no longer uses them.
  2. Attach minimal roles
    • Gather the API calls the service makes (Cloud Datastore, Pub/Sub, Secret Manager).
    • Grant predefined roles such as roles/datastore.user or create a custom role limited to those permissions.
    • Scope resource bindings to specific projects or service-account-level conditions (resource.name.startsWith("projects/prod-db")).
  3. Harden impersonation paths
    • Add an Organization Policy denying iam.serviceAccountTokenCreator on all principals except your CI/CD and monitoring identities.
    • Set Service Account Keys Disable new key creation; use Workload Identity Federation or short-lived OAuth tokens instead.
  4. Monitor and prune
    • Turn on Policy Analyzer to flag unused permissions and remove them quarterly.
    • Export IAM logs to Cloud Logging; alert on role grants that include roles/owner, roles/editor, or wildcard *.

Applying strict, role-specific service accounts limits blast radius if code or credentials are compromised and keeps the deployment compliant with Googles security best-practice guidance.

References

  • Google Cloud IAM best practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Create App Engine firewall rules
countermeasure.desc:
Create an App Engine firewall rule set that blocks all inbound requests by default and then allows traffic only from trusted sourcessuch as your company VPN, load-balancer IP ranges, or Cloud CDNbefore the request ever reaches your application code.

Implementation guidance

  1. block first, then allow
    • In Cloud Console App Engine Firewall, add rule 1000 DENY IP-RANGE 0.0.0.0/0 and rule 1001 DENY IP-RANGE ::/0.
    • Insert lower-numbered rules (e.g., 100199) that ALLOW trusted CIDRs:
      • corporate VPN: 203.0.113.0/24
      • internal Google services: 35.191.0.0/16, 130.211.0.0/22 (for Cloud Load Balancing / Cloud CDN).
  2. use service accounts for server-to-server calls
    • For Cloud Functions, Cloud Run, or other GCP workloads that must call the service, route through an internal load balancer or VPC Service Controls and do not open a broad allow rule.

  3. automate with gcloud / IaC

    1. gcloud app firewall-rules replace rules.yaml      # declarative file

      gcloud app firewall-rules list                    # verify order 

    Manage rules.yaml in your Terraform or Cloud Build pipeline so any console edits are overwritten by the next deploy.

  4. monitor & review
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine firewall; create an alert on any DENY hit to detect reconnaissance.
    • Re-audit the rule list quarterlyremove obsolete CIDRs and confirm the final deny-all rule remains in place.

With a deny-by-default firewall and tight allow-list, your App Engine service is reachable only from approved networks, reducing the risk of automated scanning, credential-stuffing, or data exfiltration.

References

  • Creating App Engine firewall rules

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that every request to your App Engine service travels over an encrypted channel by combining an automatic HTTPHTTPS redirect with Google-managed TLS certificates:

  1. enforce HTTPS redirection
    • In app.yaml, add
      • handlers:
        - url: /.*
         secure: always      # redirects http to https
         redirect_http_response_code: 301
    • For flexible-env or custom routes, set Secure = Always in the Google Cloud console (App Engine Services Version -> Edit traffic).
  2. use google-managed certificates
    • Navigate to Cloud Load Balancing Certificates and create a Google-managed certificate for your custom domain (DNS-validated).
    • Attach the cert to your App Engine custom-domain mapping; Google provisions and auto-renews itno manual rotation.
  3. verify & monitor
    • Test http://yourdomainit should return 301 to https://....
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine; create an alert on any residual http requests to catch misconfigurations.

Redirecting HTTP to HTTPS eliminates plaintext exposure, while managed certificates ensure strong, automatically renewed TLS without operational overhead.

References

  • Overview of app security

countermeasure.name: Restrict ingress settings
countermeasure.desc:
Limit where HTTP requests can originate so your App Engine service is reachable only from approved networks or Googles load-balancer front-end.

  1. Set ingress restriction in app.yaml (flex) or service settings (standard)
    1. network:
       forwarded_ports: []
       session_affinity: false
       ingress_settings: internal_and_cloud_load_balancing   # rejects direct internet traffic
    • internal blocks everything except traffic from the same VPC.
    • internal_and_cloud_load_balancing lets requests through Google Cloud HTTP(S) Load Balancing but rejects direct public IP hits.
  2. Pair with an external HTTPS load balancer or Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
    • Expose the service through Cloud Load Balancing; terminate TLS there and apply Cloud Armor rules.
    • Optionally enable IAP so even load-balanced traffic must present Google-authenticated identities.
  3. Create an allow-list firewall rule
    • In App Engine Firewall, deny 0.0.0.0/0 (rule 1000) and allow only Google Frontend IP ranges (35.191.0.0/16, 130.211.0.0/22) or your corporate VPN CIDR.
  4. Validate & monitor
    • Try to curl the services appspot.com URL from homeexpect HTTP 403.
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine firewall; alert on any blocked IPs to detect reconnaissance.

Restricting ingress at the platform edge prevents direct internet traffic from bypassing your WAF, TLS policies, and authentication layerssharply reducing the applications attack surface.

References

  • Google Cloud control ingress traffic to app engine

countermeasure.name: Route egress through VPC connector
countermeasure.desc:
Send every outbound connection from your App Engine serviceSQL, Redis, third-party APIsthrough a Serverless VPC Access connector instead of the default public interface.
This keeps traffic on Googles private backbone, lets you apply Cloud NAT, Cloud Armor, or firewall policies, and simplifies audit logging.

Implementation guidance

  1. create a serverless vpc connector
    1. gcloud compute networks vpc-access connectors create app-connector \
         --region=us-central1 \
         --network=prod-vpc \
         --range=10.8.0.0/28
  2. Choose a /28/24 CIDR that doesnt overlap existing subnets.
  3. bind the service to the connector
    • In app.yaml add:
      • vpc_access_connector:
         name: projects/<project>/locations/us-central1/connectors/app-connector
    • Deploy: gcloud app deploy.
  4. restrict direct internet egress
    • In App Engine Firewall, keep the default deny all egress rule; allow outbound traffic only to Cloud NAT or the internal IP ranges you trust.
    • Optionally attach a Cloud NAT to the connector subnet so public calls still exit with a fixed IP you can list-allow at partners.
  5. validate & monitor
    • Use VPC Flow Logs on the connector subnet; confirm that all source IPs are in the 10.8.0.0/28 range.
    • Enable Cloud Logging for Serverless VPC Access and set alerts on connection errors or throughput ceilings.

Routing egress through a VPC connector closes the default open-internet path, gives you one choke point for inspection and firewalling, and aligns with zero-trust and compliance requirements.

References

  • Connecting to a VPC network

countermeasure.name: Run Web Security Scanner on every App Engine deployment
countermeasure.desc:
Schedule an automated Web Security Scanner scan for every App Engine service (and version) so common web-app flawsXSS, mixed content, outdated libraries, misconfigured CSPare found and fixed before users encounter them.

Implementation guidance

  1. create a scan configuration
    • Console Security Web Security Scanner Create scan config.
    • Target URL: https://<service-id>-dot-<project>.appspot.com/* or your custom domain.
    • Scan type: OWASP top 10; enable out-of-band testing if the app allows file upload or email.
  2. trigger on every release
    • Add a Cloud Build step or GitHub Action that calls
      • gcloud web-security-scanner scan-runs start \
         --scan-config=<config-id>
    • Wait for the scan to finish (scan-runs describe) and fail the pipeline if any HIGH or CRITICAL findings appear.
  3. tighten authentication
    • If the app requires login, configure custom authentication (OAuth or form-based) so the scanner tests the authenticated surface area.
    • Store credentials in Secret Manager and inject them via Cloud Build substitution.
  4. remediate & track
    • Findings surface in Security Command Center; create an alert policy that opens a ticket for every new finding with severity HIGH.
    • Verify the fix by rerunning the scan or waiting for the next scheduled nightly run.

Running Web Security Scanner continuously builds a feedback loop that catches regressions early and proves compliance with Google, PCI, and OWASP security standards.

References

  • Overview of Web Security Scanner

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)

countermeasure.name: Set up IAM access control
countermeasure.desc:
Replace the broad Owner/Editor grants that Google Cloud assigns by default with custom, purpose-built IAM roles so every human user and App Engine service account has only the permissions it truly needsnothing more.

implementation guidance

  1. inventory current access
    • In Cloud Console IAM, export the policy to CSV; flag any principal that still has roles/owner or roles/editor.
    • Use the gcloud iam roles describe command or Policy Analyzer to list the permissions those principals actually exercised in the last 90 days.
  2. create custom roles
    • For developers: start with roles/appengine.deployer and add only the extra APIs they require (Cloud Run, Cloud Build).
    • For service accounts: grant roles/datastore.user, roles/pubsub.publisher, etc., scoped to the specific resources each app accesses.
  3. migrate and revoke
    • Replace basic roles with the new custom roles via gcloud projects remove-iam-policy-binding followed by add-iam-policy-binding.
    • Set an Organization Policy that denies future bindings to roles/owner and roles/editor.
  4. enforce least privilege continuously
    • Enable IAM Recommender and Policy Analyzer; review unused permissions every quarter and prune them.
    • Turn on Cloud Audit Logs for SetIamPolicy; create an alert when someone tries to assign a basic role.

Following this process limits blast radius if an account is compromised and satisfies the principle of least privilege for both deployment pipelines and runtime service accounts.

References

  • GCP IAM best practices

countermeasure.name: Upgrade to supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
Periodically audit every App Engine service and upgrade any application running on an end-of-life or deprecated runtime version so you continue to receive security patches and Google support.

how to implement

  1. inventory runtimes
    • Console App Engine Versions or run gcloud app versions list to capture the language and runtime for each deployed version.
    • Flag anything shown as deprecated or that is missing from Googles supported-runtime matrix.
  2. upgrade in lower environments first
    • Update app.yaml or your Docker base image to the latest stable runtime (for example, runtime: python311 instead of python27).
    • Deploy to dev and staging projects; run automated and manual tests to confirm compatibility.
  3. promote to production via IaC
    • Merge the runtime update into your main branch and deploy with gcloud app deploy --promote.
    • Make sure the prior version remains in traffic-splitting or serving 0 % state until rollback windows close.
  4. set a recurring review
    • Add a quarterly calendar task or CI job that compares deployed runtimes to the current support list; open a ticket if mismatches exist.
    • Subscribe to Google Cloud release notes for deprecation announcements.

Staying on supported runtimes keeps your application within the patch window, ensures compatibility with new App Engine features, and avoids surprise outages when Google retires legacy environments.

References

  • Runtime support schedule

countermeasure.name: Use minimum TLS 1.2
countermeasure.desc:
Make sure every inbound connection to your App Engine service (custom domains and the default appspot.com URL) negotiates at least TLS 1.2 so weak, out-of-date ciphers and protocols are never accepted.

  1. use a modern ssl policy
    • If you front App Engine with an external HTTPS load balancer (recommended), attach the Google-managed SSL policy TLS_POLICY_GOOGLE_STRICT or create a custom policy that disables TLS 1.0/1.1 and static-key cipher suites.
    • In Cloud Console Load Balancing Frontend configuration SSL policy, choose the strict or custom policy and save.
  2. require https inside the app
    • In app.yaml add
      • handlers:
        - url: /.*
         secure: always          # forces redirect to https
         redirect_http_response_code: 301
    • This guarantees clients are sent to HTTPS even if they reach the service via plain HTTP.
  3. verify certificate strength
    • Use a Google-managed certificate or an uploaded cert with at least a 2048-bit RSA or P-256 ECDSA key.
    • Test with openssl s_client -connect yourdomain:443 -tls1_1 the handshake must fail; repeat with -tls1_2 and expect success.
  4. monitor & alert
    • Enable Cloud Logging for the load balancer; create a metrics-based alert on any TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION = "TLS1" events to detect fallback.
    • Add a weekly SSL Labs scan in CI; fail the build if TLS 1.0/1.1 appears.

Enforcing TLS 1.2+ protects session cookies, API tokens, and user data from downgrade attacks and keeps the service compliant with modern security standards (PCI DSS v4, NIST 800-52r2).

References

  • Restrict TLS versions

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unrestricted network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Firewall rules that allow unrestricted inbound traffic (e.g., from 0.0.0.0/0) expose the App Engine application to the entire internet. This increases the attack surface, allowing anyone to probe for vulnerabilities, launch denial-of-service attacks, or attempt to exploit the application and its underlying services directly.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners, botnets, and opportunistic attackers.
  • Vectors: Direct scanning for application vulnerabilities (e.g., SQLi, XSS). Launching volumetric DDoS or application-layer DoS attacks. Brute-forcing login endpoints or other sensitive parts of the application.

Impacts

  • Denial of Service (DoS): The application can be overwhelmed with traffic, leading to high costs and making it unavailable for legitimate users.
  • Increased Exposure: Vulnerabilities in the application code are easier for attackers to find and exploit.
  • Unauthorized Access Attempts: Open access facilitates brute-force attacks on authentication endpoints without any network-level barrier.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A botnet floods the App Engine endpoint with traffic, causing it to scale up rapidly and incur massive costs, effectively making the service unusable.
  • An attacker runs a vulnerability scanner against the application's IP address, discovering an outdated library with a known remote code execution (RCE) flaw.
  • A malicious script continuously attempts to log in to an admin portal by cycling through common credentials, an attack that a more restrictive firewall could have mitigated.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Applications running on unsupported runtimes are exposed to unpatched, publicly known vulnerabilities, creating a high risk of compromise.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners and opportunistic attackers.
  • Vectors: Exploiting known CVEs in the runtime or its core libraries to trigger flaws and gain control.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers can execute arbitrary commands on the App Engine instance.
  • Data Breach: Sensitive application and user data can be stolen or exposed.
  • Denial of Service: Exploits can crash application instances, causing service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker exploits a known deserialization flaw in an outdated Python 2.7 runtime to execute malicious code.
  • A public CVE in an old Node.js version is used to bypass authorization checks and access restricted data.
  • An automated tool finds an app on a deprecated Java runtime and uses a known XML vulnerability to read application source code.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Weak or improperly configured access controls within the application or its IAM policies allow users to perform actions they are not authorized for. This includes anonymous users accessing sensitive data or authenticated users escalating their privileges to gain administrative control over the application or underlying cloud resources.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious external attackers, disgruntled insiders, or even regular users who stumble upon a flaw.
  • Vectors: Manipulating URL parameters to access other users' records (Insecure Direct Object Reference). Exploiting missing function-level access control to call admin APIs. Abusing overly permissive service account roles attached to the App Engine service.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized viewing, modification, or deletion of sensitive user or application data.
  • Privilege Escalation: A low-privileged user gains higher-level permissions, potentially leading to a full application takeover.
  • Unauthorized Resource Manipulation: Attackers could modify or delete other GCP resources if the App Engine service account has excessive permissions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A user changes the ?invoice_id=123 parameter in the URL to ?invoice_id=124 and successfully views another user's invoice.
  • An attacker discovers an unprotected admin endpoint like /api/v1/set-admin?user=attacker@evil.com and directly calls it to make themselves an administrator.
  • A vulnerability in the application allows an attacker to use App Engine's overly broad service account permissions to delete a production Cloud SQL database.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted or weak data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted between the client and the App Engine application without encryption (HTTP) or using weak, outdated TLS configurations is vulnerable to interception. This allows attackers positioned between the user and the server to read, modify, or steal sensitive information in transit, including credentials, personal data, and session tokens.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Attackers on the same local network (e.g., public Wi-Fi), compromised network devices, or state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Performing Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks to intercept plaintext HTTP traffic. Exploiting weak TLS ciphers or protocols (e.g., SSLv3, TLS 1.0) to decrypt HTTPS traffic. Using SSL stripping attacks to downgrade a connection from HTTPS to HTTP.

Impacts

  • Data Eavesdropping: Confidential data such as login credentials, payment information, and personal details can be stolen.
  • Session Hijacking: An attacker can capture a user's session cookie and impersonate them to take over their account.
  • Data Integrity Violation: Attackers can modify data in transit, for instance, by injecting malicious content into a webpage served to the user.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A user connects to an application over public Wi-Fi using HTTP, and an attacker on the same network captures their password upon login.
  • An attacker exploits a weak TLS 1.0 configuration on the application's custom domain to decrypt a user's session and hijack their authenticated session.
  • A proxy server performs an SSL stripping attack, forcing a user's browser to connect via HTTP, thereby exposing all transmitted data for that session.

threat.name: Open ingress paths
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfigured ingress paths or overly broad routing rules in the application's configuration (app.yaml or dispatch files) can expose internal APIs, admin consoles, or sensitive files. This allows attackers to bypass intended security controls and directly access application components that should not be publicly available.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners, curious users, and malicious attackers.
  • Vectors: Guessing common sensitive paths (/admin, /status, /debug). Exploiting wildcard routes (/.*) that inadvertently map to internal logic. Accessing static files containing secrets that were mistakenly uploaded and mapped.

Impacts

  • Information Disclosure: Exposure of sensitive data, application configuration, or source code.
  • Security Control Bypass: Gaining access to administrative functions or internal APIs without proper authentication or authorization.
  • Increased Attack Surface: Revealing additional endpoints that can be probed for other vulnerabilities like SQL injection or RCE.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker scans for common paths and discovers an unprotected /admin endpoint, allowing them to take control of the application.
  • A configuration rule accidentally exposes a /logs directory as a static folder, allowing anyone to read sensitive application log files.
  • A developer leaves a temporary /debug/pprof endpoint enabled in production, which an attacker finds and uses to analyze application performance and extract runtime information.

threat.name: Unmonitored egress traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of monitoring on outbound (egress) network traffic from App Engine makes it difficult to detect when a compromised application is communicating with an attacker's server. If an attacker gains control of the application, they can establish connections to external systems to exfiltrate data or receive further commands without raising any alarms.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Remote code exploits, malicious software dependencies (supply-chain attack), or malicious insiders.
  • Vectors: A compromised application sending stolen data to an attacker-controlled server. An exploited application instance being used as a pivot point to scan or attack other external or internal systems. Establishing a reverse shell to an external command-and-control (C2) server.

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data from the application or its connected databases can be stolen without detection.
  • Command and Control (C2): Attackers can maintain persistent control over the compromised instance, using it for further malicious activities.
  • Attack Pivoting: The App Engine instance can be used as part of a botnet or to launch attacks against other targets, making the traffic appear to originate from Google.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A vulnerability allows an attacker to run code that zips up customer data and sends it via an HTTPS POST request to an external server they control.
  • A malicious dependency included in the application opens a reverse shell, connecting to an attacker's C2 server to await commands.
  • An exploited instance is used to perform port scanning and vulnerability discovery against a third-party corporate partner, obfuscating the true origin of the attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Undetected application vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerabilities within the application's own source code, such as SQL injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), or insecure deserialization, go unnoticed without security scanning or code reviews. These flaws can be exploited by attackers to compromise data, hijack user sessions, or gain control over the application, regardless of the security of the underlying App Engine platform.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious external attackers, automated scanners, or even authenticated users exploiting privilege flaws.
  • Vectors: Submitting crafted input to exploit SQL injection flaws in database queries. Injecting malicious scripts into application pages to perform XSS attacks on other users. Sending specially formatted data to trigger remote code execution via insecure deserialization.

Impacts

  • Data Compromise: Attackers can steal, modify, or delete sensitive data from the application's database.
  • User Account Takeover: Hijacking user sessions or stealing credentials via XSS or other injection flaws.
  • Remote Code Execution: Gaining a shell or executing arbitrary commands on the App Engine instance, leading to a full system compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker enters ' OR '1'='1 into a search field, exploiting a SQL injection vulnerability to dump the entire user database.
  • A malicious user posts a comment containing a JavaScript payload, which executes in the browsers of administrators who view the comment, stealing their session cookies.
  • An attacker submits a malicious object to a Java application that deserializes user input without validation, resulting in remote code execution on the App Engine instance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-1283
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1283: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

weakness.name: CWE-208
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.
In security-relevant contexts, even small variations in timing can be exploited by attackers to indirectly infer certain details about the product's internal operations. For example, in some cryptographic algorithms, attackers can use timing differences to infer certain properties about a private key, making the key easier to guess. Timing discrepancies effectively form a timing side channel.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-601
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect') A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks. An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance. Whether this issue poses a vulnerability will be subject to the intended behavior of the application. For example, a search engine might intentionally provide redirects to arbitrary URLs.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-912
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-912: Hidden Functionality The product contains functionality that is not documented, not part of the specification, and not accessible through an interface or command sequence that is obvious to the product's users or administrators. Hidden functionality can take many forms, such as intentionally malicious code, "Easter Eggs" that contain extraneous functionality such as games, developer-friendly shortcuts that reduce maintenance or support costs such as hard-coded accounts, etc. From a security perspective, even when the functionality is not intentionally malicious or damaging, it can increase the product's attack surface and expose additional weaknesses beyond what is already exposed by the intended functionality. Even if it is not easily accessible, the hidden functionality could be useful for attacks that modify the control flow of the application.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege to service accounts
countermeasure.desc:
Create one dedicated service account for each App Engine service or environment and attach only the IAM roles that the code truly needsnothing more, never Editor or Owner.

Implementation guidance

  1. Provision purpose-built accounts
    • Console IAM & Admin Service Accounts Create, give each account a descriptive name (e.g., sa-billing-api-prod).
    • Disable the default App Engine and Compute Engine service accounts if your workload no longer uses them.
  2. Attach minimal roles
    • Gather the API calls the service makes (Cloud Datastore, Pub/Sub, Secret Manager).
    • Grant predefined roles such as roles/datastore.user or create a custom role limited to those permissions.
    • Scope resource bindings to specific projects or service-account-level conditions (resource.name.startsWith("projects/prod-db")).
  3. Harden impersonation paths
    • Add an Organization Policy denying iam.serviceAccountTokenCreator on all principals except your CI/CD and monitoring identities.
    • Set Service Account Keys Disable new key creation; use Workload Identity Federation or short-lived OAuth tokens instead.
  4. Monitor and prune
    • Turn on Policy Analyzer to flag unused permissions and remove them quarterly.
    • Export IAM logs to Cloud Logging; alert on role grants that include roles/owner, roles/editor, or wildcard *.

Applying strict, role-specific service accounts limits blast radius if code or credentials are compromised and keeps the deployment compliant with Googles security best-practice guidance.

References

  • Google Cloud IAM best practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Create App Engine firewall rules
countermeasure.desc:
Create an App Engine firewall rule set that blocks all inbound requests by default and then allows traffic only from trusted sourcessuch as your company VPN, load-balancer IP ranges, or Cloud CDNbefore the request ever reaches your application code.

Implementation guidance

  1. block first, then allow
    • In Cloud Console App Engine Firewall, add rule 1000 DENY IP-RANGE 0.0.0.0/0 and rule 1001 DENY IP-RANGE ::/0.
    • Insert lower-numbered rules (e.g., 100199) that ALLOW trusted CIDRs:
      • corporate VPN: 203.0.113.0/24
      • internal Google services: 35.191.0.0/16, 130.211.0.0/22 (for Cloud Load Balancing / Cloud CDN).
  2. use service accounts for server-to-server calls
    • For Cloud Functions, Cloud Run, or other GCP workloads that must call the service, route through an internal load balancer or VPC Service Controls and do not open a broad allow rule.

  3. automate with gcloud / IaC

    1. gcloud app firewall-rules replace rules.yaml      # declarative file

      gcloud app firewall-rules list                    # verify order 

    Manage rules.yaml in your Terraform or Cloud Build pipeline so any console edits are overwritten by the next deploy.

  4. monitor & review
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine firewall; create an alert on any DENY hit to detect reconnaissance.
    • Re-audit the rule list quarterlyremove obsolete CIDRs and confirm the final deny-all rule remains in place.

With a deny-by-default firewall and tight allow-list, your App Engine service is reachable only from approved networks, reducing the risk of automated scanning, credential-stuffing, or data exfiltration.

References

  • Creating App Engine firewall rules

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that every request to your App Engine service travels over an encrypted channel by combining an automatic HTTPHTTPS redirect with Google-managed TLS certificates:

  1. enforce HTTPS redirection
    • In app.yaml, add
      • handlers:
        - url: /.*
         secure: always      # redirects http to https
         redirect_http_response_code: 301
    • For flexible-env or custom routes, set Secure = Always in the Google Cloud console (App Engine Services Version -> Edit traffic).
  2. use google-managed certificates
    • Navigate to Cloud Load Balancing Certificates and create a Google-managed certificate for your custom domain (DNS-validated).
    • Attach the cert to your App Engine custom-domain mapping; Google provisions and auto-renews itno manual rotation.
  3. verify & monitor
    • Test http://yourdomainit should return 301 to https://....
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine; create an alert on any residual http requests to catch misconfigurations.

Redirecting HTTP to HTTPS eliminates plaintext exposure, while managed certificates ensure strong, automatically renewed TLS without operational overhead.

References

  • Overview of app security

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed

countermeasure.name: Restrict ingress settings
countermeasure.desc:
Limit where HTTP requests can originate so your App Engine service is reachable only from approved networks or Googles load-balancer front-end.

  1. Set ingress restriction in app.yaml (flex) or service settings (standard)
    1. network:
       forwarded_ports: []
       session_affinity: false
       ingress_settings: internal_and_cloud_load_balancing   # rejects direct internet traffic
    • internal blocks everything except traffic from the same VPC.
    • internal_and_cloud_load_balancing lets requests through Google Cloud HTTP(S) Load Balancing but rejects direct public IP hits.
  2. Pair with an external HTTPS load balancer or Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
    • Expose the service through Cloud Load Balancing; terminate TLS there and apply Cloud Armor rules.
    • Optionally enable IAP so even load-balanced traffic must present Google-authenticated identities.
  3. Create an allow-list firewall rule
    • In App Engine Firewall, deny 0.0.0.0/0 (rule 1000) and allow only Google Frontend IP ranges (35.191.0.0/16, 130.211.0.0/22) or your corporate VPN CIDR.
  4. Validate & monitor
    • Try to curl the services appspot.com URL from homeexpect HTTP 403.
    • Enable Cloud Logging for App Engine firewall; alert on any blocked IPs to detect reconnaissance.

Restricting ingress at the platform edge prevents direct internet traffic from bypassing your WAF, TLS policies, and authentication layerssharply reducing the applications attack surface.

References

  • Google Cloud control ingress traffic to app engine

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Route egress through VPC connector
countermeasure.desc:
Send every outbound connection from your App Engine serviceSQL, Redis, third-party APIsthrough a Serverless VPC Access connector instead of the default public interface.
This keeps traffic on Googles private backbone, lets you apply Cloud NAT, Cloud Armor, or firewall policies, and simplifies audit logging.

Implementation guidance

  1. create a serverless vpc connector
    1. gcloud compute networks vpc-access connectors create app-connector \
         --region=us-central1 \
         --network=prod-vpc \
         --range=10.8.0.0/28
  2. Choose a /28/24 CIDR that doesnt overlap existing subnets.
  3. bind the service to the connector
    • In app.yaml add:
      • vpc_access_connector:
         name: projects/<project>/locations/us-central1/connectors/app-connector
    • Deploy: gcloud app deploy.
  4. restrict direct internet egress
    • In App Engine Firewall, keep the default deny all egress rule; allow outbound traffic only to Cloud NAT or the internal IP ranges you trust.
    • Optionally attach a Cloud NAT to the connector subnet so public calls still exit with a fixed IP you can list-allow at partners.
  5. validate & monitor
    • Use VPC Flow Logs on the connector subnet; confirm that all source IPs are in the 10.8.0.0/28 range.
    • Enable Cloud Logging for Serverless VPC Access and set alerts on connection errors or throughput ceilings.

Routing egress through a VPC connector closes the default open-internet path, gives you one choke point for inspection and firewalling, and aligns with zero-trust and compliance requirements.

References

  • Connecting to a VPC network

countermeasure.name: Run Web Security Scanner on every App Engine deployment
countermeasure.desc:
Schedule an automated Web Security Scanner scan for every App Engine service (and version) so common web-app flawsXSS, mixed content, outdated libraries, misconfigured CSPare found and fixed before users encounter them.

Implementation guidance

  1. create a scan configuration
    • Console Security Web Security Scanner Create scan config.
    • Target URL: https://<service-id>-dot-<project>.appspot.com/* or your custom domain.
    • Scan type: OWASP top 10; enable out-of-band testing if the app allows file upload or email.
  2. trigger on every release
    • Add a Cloud Build step or GitHub Action that calls
      • gcloud web-security-scanner scan-runs start \
         --scan-config=<config-id>
    • Wait for the scan to finish (scan-runs describe) and fail the pipeline if any HIGH or CRITICAL findings appear.
  3. tighten authentication
    • If the app requires login, configure custom authentication (OAuth or form-based) so the scanner tests the authenticated surface area.
    • Store credentials in Secret Manager and inject them via Cloud Build substitution.
  4. remediate & track
    • Findings surface in Security Command Center; create an alert policy that opens a ticket for every new finding with severity HIGH.
    • Verify the fix by rerunning the scan or waiting for the next scheduled nightly run.

Running Web Security Scanner continuously builds a feedback loop that catches regressions early and proves compliance with Google, PCI, and OWASP security standards.

References

  • Overview of Web Security Scanner

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Set up IAM access control
countermeasure.desc:
Replace the broad Owner/Editor grants that Google Cloud assigns by default with custom, purpose-built IAM roles so every human user and App Engine service account has only the permissions it truly needsnothing more.

implementation guidance

  1. inventory current access
    • In Cloud Console IAM, export the policy to CSV; flag any principal that still has roles/owner or roles/editor.
    • Use the gcloud iam roles describe command or Policy Analyzer to list the permissions those principals actually exercised in the last 90 days.
  2. create custom roles
    • For developers: start with roles/appengine.deployer and add only the extra APIs they require (Cloud Run, Cloud Build).
    • For service accounts: grant roles/datastore.user, roles/pubsub.publisher, etc., scoped to the specific resources each app accesses.
  3. migrate and revoke
    • Replace basic roles with the new custom roles via gcloud projects remove-iam-policy-binding followed by add-iam-policy-binding.
    • Set an Organization Policy that denies future bindings to roles/owner and roles/editor.
  4. enforce least privilege continuously
    • Enable IAM Recommender and Policy Analyzer; review unused permissions every quarter and prune them.
    • Turn on Cloud Audit Logs for SetIamPolicy; create an alert when someone tries to assign a basic role.

Following this process limits blast radius if an account is compromised and satisfies the principle of least privilege for both deployment pipelines and runtime service accounts.

References

  • GCP IAM best practices

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Upgrade to supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
Periodically audit every App Engine service and upgrade any application running on an end-of-life or deprecated runtime version so you continue to receive security patches and Google support.

how to implement

  1. inventory runtimes
    • Console App Engine Versions or run gcloud app versions list to capture the language and runtime for each deployed version.
    • Flag anything shown as deprecated or that is missing from Googles supported-runtime matrix.
  2. upgrade in lower environments first
    • Update app.yaml or your Docker base image to the latest stable runtime (for example, runtime: python311 instead of python27).
    • Deploy to dev and staging projects; run automated and manual tests to confirm compatibility.
  3. promote to production via IaC
    • Merge the runtime update into your main branch and deploy with gcloud app deploy --promote.
    • Make sure the prior version remains in traffic-splitting or serving 0 % state until rollback windows close.
  4. set a recurring review
    • Add a quarterly calendar task or CI job that compares deployed runtimes to the current support list; open a ticket if mismatches exist.
    • Subscribe to Google Cloud release notes for deprecation announcements.

Staying on supported runtimes keeps your application within the patch window, ensures compatibility with new App Engine features, and avoids surprise outages when Google retires legacy environments.

References

  • Runtime support schedule

PM-3 Information Security and Privacy Resources

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1040 - Behavior Prevention on Endpoint

countermeasure.name: Use minimum TLS 1.2
countermeasure.desc:
Make sure every inbound connection to your App Engine service (custom domains and the default appspot.com URL) negotiates at least TLS 1.2 so weak, out-of-date ciphers and protocols are never accepted.

  1. use a modern ssl policy
    • If you front App Engine with an external HTTPS load balancer (recommended), attach the Google-managed SSL policy TLS_POLICY_GOOGLE_STRICT or create a custom policy that disables TLS 1.0/1.1 and static-key cipher suites.
    • In Cloud Console Load Balancing Frontend configuration SSL policy, choose the strict or custom policy and save.
  2. require https inside the app
    • In app.yaml add
      • handlers:
        - url: /.*
         secure: always          # forces redirect to https
         redirect_http_response_code: 301
    • This guarantees clients are sent to HTTPS even if they reach the service via plain HTTP.
  3. verify certificate strength
    • Use a Google-managed certificate or an uploaded cert with at least a 2048-bit RSA or P-256 ECDSA key.
    • Test with openssl s_client -connect yourdomain:443 -tls1_1 the handshake must fail; repeat with -tls1_2 and expect success.
  4. monitor & alert
    • Enable Cloud Logging for the load balancer; create a metrics-based alert on any TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION = "TLS1" events to detect fallback.
    • Add a weekly SSL Labs scan in CI; fail the build if TLS 1.0/1.1 appears.

Enforcing TLS 1.2+ protects session cookies, API tokens, and user data from downgrade attacks and keeps the service compliant with modern security standards (PCI DSS v4, NIST 800-52r2).

References

  • Restrict TLS versions

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unrestricted network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Firewall rules that allow unrestricted inbound traffic (e.g., from 0.0.0.0/0) expose the App Engine application to the entire internet. This increases the attack surface, allowing anyone to probe for vulnerabilities, launch denial-of-service attacks, or attempt to exploit the application and its underlying services directly.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners, botnets, and opportunistic attackers.
  • Vectors: Direct scanning for application vulnerabilities (e.g., SQLi, XSS). Launching volumetric DDoS or application-layer DoS attacks. Brute-forcing login endpoints or other sensitive parts of the application.

Impacts

  • Denial of Service (DoS): The application can be overwhelmed with traffic, leading to high costs and making it unavailable for legitimate users.
  • Increased Exposure: Vulnerabilities in the application code are easier for attackers to find and exploit.
  • Unauthorized Access Attempts: Open access facilitates brute-force attacks on authentication endpoints without any network-level barrier.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A botnet floods the App Engine endpoint with traffic, causing it to scale up rapidly and incur massive costs, effectively making the service unusable.
  • An attacker runs a vulnerability scanner against the application's IP address, discovering an outdated library with a known remote code execution (RCE) flaw.
  • A malicious script continuously attempts to log in to an admin portal by cycling through common credentials, an attack that a more restrictive firewall could have mitigated.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Applications running on unsupported runtimes are exposed to unpatched, publicly known vulnerabilities, creating a high risk of compromise.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners and opportunistic attackers.
  • Vectors: Exploiting known CVEs in the runtime or its core libraries to trigger flaws and gain control.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers can execute arbitrary commands on the App Engine instance.
  • Data Breach: Sensitive application and user data can be stolen or exposed.
  • Denial of Service: Exploits can crash application instances, causing service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker exploits a known deserialization flaw in an outdated Python 2.7 runtime to execute malicious code.
  • A public CVE in an old Node.js version is used to bypass authorization checks and access restricted data.
  • An automated tool finds an app on a deprecated Java runtime and uses a known XML vulnerability to read application source code.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Weak or improperly configured access controls within the application or its IAM policies allow users to perform actions they are not authorized for. This includes anonymous users accessing sensitive data or authenticated users escalating their privileges to gain administrative control over the application or underlying cloud resources.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious external attackers, disgruntled insiders, or even regular users who stumble upon a flaw.
  • Vectors: Manipulating URL parameters to access other users' records (Insecure Direct Object Reference). Exploiting missing function-level access control to call admin APIs. Abusing overly permissive service account roles attached to the App Engine service.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized viewing, modification, or deletion of sensitive user or application data.
  • Privilege Escalation: A low-privileged user gains higher-level permissions, potentially leading to a full application takeover.
  • Unauthorized Resource Manipulation: Attackers could modify or delete other GCP resources if the App Engine service account has excessive permissions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A user changes the ?invoice_id=123 parameter in the URL to ?invoice_id=124 and successfully views another user's invoice.
  • An attacker discovers an unprotected admin endpoint like /api/v1/set-admin?user=attacker@evil.com and directly calls it to make themselves an administrator.
  • A vulnerability in the application allows an attacker to use App Engine's overly broad service account permissions to delete a production Cloud SQL database.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted or weak data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted between the client and the App Engine application without encryption (HTTP) or using weak, outdated TLS configurations is vulnerable to interception. This allows attackers positioned between the user and the server to read, modify, or steal sensitive information in transit, including credentials, personal data, and session tokens.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Attackers on the same local network (e.g., public Wi-Fi), compromised network devices, or state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Performing Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks to intercept plaintext HTTP traffic. Exploiting weak TLS ciphers or protocols (e.g., SSLv3, TLS 1.0) to decrypt HTTPS traffic. Using SSL stripping attacks to downgrade a connection from HTTPS to HTTP.

Impacts

  • Data Eavesdropping: Confidential data such as login credentials, payment information, and personal details can be stolen.
  • Session Hijacking: An attacker can capture a user's session cookie and impersonate them to take over their account.
  • Data Integrity Violation: Attackers can modify data in transit, for instance, by injecting malicious content into a webpage served to the user.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A user connects to an application over public Wi-Fi using HTTP, and an attacker on the same network captures their password upon login.
  • An attacker exploits a weak TLS 1.0 configuration on the application's custom domain to decrypt a user's session and hijack their authenticated session.
  • A proxy server performs an SSL stripping attack, forcing a user's browser to connect via HTTP, thereby exposing all transmitted data for that session.

threat.name: Open ingress paths
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfigured ingress paths or overly broad routing rules in the application's configuration (app.yaml or dispatch files) can expose internal APIs, admin consoles, or sensitive files. This allows attackers to bypass intended security controls and directly access application components that should not be publicly available.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Automated scanners, curious users, and malicious attackers.
  • Vectors: Guessing common sensitive paths (/admin, /status, /debug). Exploiting wildcard routes (/.*) that inadvertently map to internal logic. Accessing static files containing secrets that were mistakenly uploaded and mapped.

Impacts

  • Information Disclosure: Exposure of sensitive data, application configuration, or source code.
  • Security Control Bypass: Gaining access to administrative functions or internal APIs without proper authentication or authorization.
  • Increased Attack Surface: Revealing additional endpoints that can be probed for other vulnerabilities like SQL injection or RCE.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker scans for common paths and discovers an unprotected /admin endpoint, allowing them to take control of the application.
  • A configuration rule accidentally exposes a /logs directory as a static folder, allowing anyone to read sensitive application log files.
  • A developer leaves a temporary /debug/pprof endpoint enabled in production, which an attacker finds and uses to analyze application performance and extract runtime information.

threat.name: Unmonitored egress traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of monitoring on outbound (egress) network traffic from App Engine makes it difficult to detect when a compromised application is communicating with an attacker's server. If an attacker gains control of the application, they can establish connections to external systems to exfiltrate data or receive further commands without raising any alarms.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Remote code exploits, malicious software dependencies (supply-chain attack), or malicious insiders.
  • Vectors: A compromised application sending stolen data to an attacker-controlled server. An exploited application instance being used as a pivot point to scan or attack other external or internal systems. Establishing a reverse shell to an external command-and-control (C2) server.

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive data from the application or its connected databases can be stolen without detection.
  • Command and Control (C2): Attackers can maintain persistent control over the compromised instance, using it for further malicious activities.
  • Attack Pivoting: The App Engine instance can be used as part of a botnet or to launch attacks against other targets, making the traffic appear to originate from Google.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A vulnerability allows an attacker to run code that zips up customer data and sends it via an HTTPS POST request to an external server they control.
  • A malicious dependency included in the application opens a reverse shell, connecting to an attacker's C2 server to await commands.
  • An exploited instance is used to perform port scanning and vulnerability discovery against a third-party corporate partner, obfuscating the true origin of the attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Undetected application vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerabilities within the application's own source code, such as SQL injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), or insecure deserialization, go unnoticed without security scanning or code reviews. These flaws can be exploited by attackers to compromise data, hijack user sessions, or gain control over the application, regardless of the security of the underlying App Engine platform.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious external attackers, automated scanners, or even authenticated users exploiting privilege flaws.
  • Vectors: Submitting crafted input to exploit SQL injection flaws in database queries. Injecting malicious scripts into application pages to perform XSS attacks on other users. Sending specially formatted data to trigger remote code execution via insecure deserialization.

Impacts

  • Data Compromise: Attackers can steal, modify, or delete sensitive data from the application's database.
  • User Account Takeover: Hijacking user sessions or stealing credentials via XSS or other injection flaws.
  • Remote Code Execution: Gaining a shell or executing arbitrary commands on the App Engine instance, leading to a full system compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker enters ' OR '1'='1 into a search field, exploiting a SQL injection vulnerability to dump the entire user database.
  • A malicious user posts a comment containing a JavaScript payload, which executes in the browsers of administrators who view the comment, stealing their session cookies.
  • An attacker submits a malicious object to a Java application that deserializes user input without validation, resulting in remote code execution on the App Engine instance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege for DNS record management
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Cloud IAM roles and permissions to implement the principle of least privilege for DNS record management. Ensure that only authorized users with specific roles can modify DNS records. Assign permissions carefully, restricting access to users or services that need it to minimize the risk of unauthorized changes. Regularly review and audit permissions to ensure compliance with security best practices and remove excessive or outdated access rights.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Configure DNS queries to use HTTPS for encrypted transmission
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all DNS queries are sent over HTTPS (DNS over HTTPS, or DoH) to protect data in transit from being intercepted or tampered with by malicious actors. By encrypting DNS traffic, you safeguard DNS queries and responses from potential man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensure that sensitive information is not exposed on the network. Regularly verify that all DNS traffic is encrypted using DoH to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNS Security Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable DNSSEC to authenticate DNS responses
countermeasure.desc:
Enable DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions) for your Cloud DNS managed zones to protect against DNS spoofing attacks. DNSSEC uses digital signatures to authenticate DNS responses, ensuring that clients only receive valid and untampered responses from authoritative DNS servers. Implement DNSSEC to prevent attackers from injecting fraudulent DNS data and redirecting traffic to malicious websites. Regularly monitor DNSSEC configurations to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNSSEC Documentation

Enable logging for all changes to DNS records in GCP to ensure a comprehensive audit trail of DNS modifications. Use Cloud Logging to track and monitor any changes made to DNS settings, and regularly review the logs to identify suspicious or unauthorized activity. Additionally, set up alerts to notify administrators of any unauthorized modifications or anomalies in real-time, enabling a prompt response to potential security threats.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging for DNS changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of logging for DNS changes can result in unauthorized modifications going unnoticed. Without proper logging and monitoring, malicious actors or insider threats could alter DNS records, redirecting traffic or compromising services. Failure to detect such changes can lead to prolonged exposure to attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, or users with excessive privileges.
  • Attack Vectors: Unauthorized or unnoticed DNS record changes due to lack of logging or monitoring.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious sites.
  • Service disruptions or unavailability of services due to incorrect DNS configurations.
  • Prolonged compromise due to delayed detection of malicious changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A malicious insider makes unauthorized changes to DNS records, redirecting traffic to a malicious site without being detected because DNS change logs are not monitored.
  2. An attacker with stolen credentials modifies DNS records to launch a phishing campaign, and the changes go unnoticed for days due to the lack of DNS logging and alerts.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: DNS cache poisoning
threat.desc:
General threat description
DNS cache poisoning occurs when an attacker manipulates the cache of a DNS resolver, injecting fraudulent IP addresses for legitimate domain names. This redirects users to malicious websites without their knowledge, leading to data theft, malware distribution, or phishing attacks. Without DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions), DNS responses are vulnerable to tampering, making cache poisoning a critical risk.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised DNS resolvers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weaknesses in DNS query/response processes to inject false information into DNS caches.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to malicious websites, resulting in phishing, data theft, or malware infection.
  • Loss of customer trust and potential brand damage.
  • Compromise of critical infrastructure if services are redirected to attacker-controlled locations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker injects a fake IP address into the DNS cache of a resolver, causing users trying to visit a legitimate banking website to be redirected to a phishing site.
  2. A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a DNS server, poisoning its cache and redirecting traffic meant for a popular online service to a server under their control, where they steal user credentials.

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attacks on DNS queries
threat.desc:
General threat description
A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack on DNS queries occurs when an attacker intercepts or alters DNS requests and responses between the client and DNS server. By doing so, the attacker can redirect users to malicious websites, steal sensitive information, or disrupt services. DNS queries that are not encrypted or authenticated are particularly vulnerable to such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious network intermediaries, or compromised routers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted DNS traffic, modifying DNS responses in transit, or spoofing DNS servers to redirect traffic.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to fraudulent or malicious websites.
  • Data theft, including login credentials or sensitive user information.
  • Service disruption or compromise, resulting in downtime or reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker performs a MitM attack by intercepting DNS queries over an unsecured network and responds with malicious IP addresses, redirecting users trying to access a legitimate service to a fake site.
  2. A MitM attack targets public Wi-Fi users, intercepting DNS queries and altering responses to redirect users to a malicious website where their login credentials are stolen.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of DNS records
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized modification of DNS records occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user gains access to modify DNS settings, redirecting traffic to malicious servers or disrupting services. DNS records control how domain names are resolved into IP addresses, and tampering with these records can lead to DNS hijacking, service outages, or data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised accounts, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, using stolen credentials, or leveraging misconfigured permissions to modify DNS records.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious websites.
  • Service disruptions, causing unavailability of critical applications or services.
  • Data theft or phishing attacks, leading to financial loss and reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the DNS management console using stolen credentials and modifies DNS records to redirect website visitors to a malicious server for phishing.
  2. A malicious insider with excessive privileges changes DNS settings, causing a company's email traffic to be routed to an attacker-controlled server, leading to data interception.

weakness.name: CWE-120
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-120: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow') The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow. A buffer overflow condition exists when a product attempts to put more data in a buffer than it can hold, or when it attempts to put data in a memory area outside of the boundaries of a buffer. The simplest type of error, and the most common cause of buffer overflows, is the "classic" case in which the product copies the buffer without restricting how much is copied. Other variants exist, but the existence of a classic overflow strongly suggests that the programmer is not considering even the most basic of security protections.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-914
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-914: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.

countermeasure.name: Apply fine-grained IAM policies to restrict access to Firestore collections and documents
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every principaluser, service account, or workload identityhas only the minimum permissions needed on specific Firestore paths, rather than granting broad project-wide roles:

  1. identify access requirements
    • For each service or team, list exactly which collections or documents they must read (get, list) or write (create, update, delete).
    • Map these requirements to Firestore resource names, for example:
      • projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/orders/*
        projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/users/{userId}
  2. use predefined and custom roles
    • Start with Googles predefined firestore roles, such as roles/datastore.viewer or roles/datastore.user.
    • If they contain extra permissions, create a custom role limited to only the necessary methods (firestore.documents.get, firestore.documents.create, etc.).
  3. scope bindings to resource paths
    • Bind roles with IAM conditions targeting the exact document or collection:
      • gcloud projects add-iam-policy-binding my-proj \
         --member="serviceAccount:svc-order@my-proj.iam.gserviceaccount.com" \
         --role="projects/my-proj/roles/OrderWriter" \
         --condition="expression=request.resource.name.startsWith('projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/orders/'),title='OrderCollectionAccess'"
    • This prevents the service account from accessing any other Firestore data.
  4. enforce least privilege continuously
    • Enable IAM Recommender to detect unused permissions and prune them.
    • Turn on Cloud Audit Logs for firestore.googleapis.com and alert on any access outside of approved paths or principals.
  5. review and rotate
    • Quarterly, export IAM policies (gcloud projects get-iam-policy) and compare against your access matrix.
    • Remove any lingering Editor/Owner grants on Firestore, and rotate service-account keys or switch to short-lived tokens.

Applying path-based, least-privilege IAM controls ensures that even if a credential is compromised, its access is confined strictly to the allowed Firestore documents and collections.

References

  • Security for server client libraries
  • Firebase IAM permissions
