countermeasure.name: Enable logging and auditing for all IAM policy changes in Firestore
countermeasure.desc:
Capture and surface every change to Firestore IAM bindings so you can trace who granted or revoked access:

  1. Turn on Data Access audit logs
    • In Cloud Console Logging Audit Logs, ensure that for the Firestore API (firestore.googleapis.com) youve enabled Data Access logs for all principals. This records calls to SetIamPolicy, GetIamPolicy, and related methods.
  2. Export logs to a secure sink
    • Create a Logging Sink that routes Firestore audit entries to a dedicated, CMEK-encrypted Cloud Storage bucket or BigQuery dataset for long-term retention (e.g., 1 year) and forensic analysis.
  3. Alert on unexpected changes
    • Build a LogsBased Metric filtering on protoPayload.methodName="SetIamPolicy" and resource.type="firestore.googleapis.com/Database".
    • Create a Cloud Monitoring Alert on that metric to notify your security/SRE channel whenever an IAM change occurs outside normal change windows.
  4. Visualize and review
    • Use BigQuery or Cloud Loggings Log Explorer to dashboard IAM change events over time, showing the actor, timestamp, and modified policy snippets.
    • Schedule quarterly reviews of the permission-change history to detect drift or unauthorized grants.

With Data Access logs enabled, a secure sink for retention, real-time alerts, and periodic audits, youll have full visibility into every Firestore IAM policy change and can respond immediately to misconfigurations or suspicious activity.

References

  • Firestore audit logging information

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege for service accounts accessing Firestore
countermeasure.desc:
Lock down Firestore so that each user or service account can perform only the exact actions it needsno broad project-wide grants.

  1. Define access requirements
    • Inventory which collections and documents each service or team must read (get, list) or write (create, update, delete).
    • Map them to Firestore resource names, for example:
      • projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/orders/*
        projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/users/{userId}
  2. Use predefined and custom roles
    • Start with Googles predefined Firestore roles (e.g. roles/datastore.viewer, roles/datastore.user).
    • If those include extra permissions, create a custom role that lists only the needed methods (firestore.documents.get, firestore.documents.create, etc.).
  3. Scope IAM bindings to resource paths
    • Apply IAM bindings with conditions that restrict the role to the exact document or collection path:
      • gcloud projects add-iam-policy-binding my-proj \
         --member="serviceAccount:order-svc@my-proj.iam.gserviceaccount.com" \
         --role="projects/my-proj/roles/OrderWriter" \
         --condition="expression=resource.name.startsWith('projects/my-proj/databases/(default)/documents/orders/'),title='orderAccess'"
  4. Continuously enforce least privilege
    • Enable IAM Recommender to identify and remove unused permissions.
    • Turn on Cloud Audit Logs for firestore.googleapis.com and alert on any access outside approved paths or principals.

By applying path-based IAM controls and custom roles, you ensure that even if a credential is compromised, its reach is limited strictly to the allowed Firestore collections or documents.

References

  • Identity and Access Management (IAM)
  • Get started with Cloud Firestore Security Rules

countermeasure.name: Implement client-side field-level encryption for sensitive data before sending it to Firestore, using a service like Cloud KMS for key management
countermeasure.desc:
Before writing any sensitive fields (PII, financial data, health records) to Firestore, encrypt them in the client using a data-encryption key (DEK) that you generate and wrap with Cloud KMS. This ensures that plaintext never leaves the client environment.

  1. Choose a crypto library
    • Use Google Tink or another vetted crypto SDK that supports envelope encryption.
    • Embed only the minimal encryption routines in your frontend or mobile app.
  2. Generate and wrap keys
    • In your backend (or a trusted initialization step), call Cloud KMSs projects.locations.keyRings.cryptoKeys.generateRandomBytes to create a DEK.
    • Use projects.locations.keyRings.cryptoKeys.encrypt to wrap (encrypt) the DEK with your KMS key. Store the wrapped key alongside your document metadata in Firestore.
  3. Encrypt fields on the client
    • At runtime, fetch the wrapped DEK from Firestore, send it to Cloud KMSs decrypt endpoint to unwrap back into the plaintext DEK.
    • Use the DEK locally to encrypt each sensitive field (AES-GCM recommended) before constructing your Firestore document.
    • Only send the ciphertext and the wrapped DEK to Firestore, never the plaintext key.
  4. Eecrypt on the client or trusted backend
    • When reading documents, retrieve the wrapped DEK, call KMS decrypt to recover the DEK, and then decrypt each field in-memory.
    • Avoid decrypting in untrusted or shared environments (e.g., public browsers without secure storage).
  5. Rotate and revoke
    • Rotate your Cloud KMS key per policy (e.g., annually). Re-wrap DEKs without re-encrypting all data by double-wrapping or by issuing new DEKs and re-encrypting only new documents.
    • Revoke access by disabling the KMS crypto key; existing clients will fail to unwrap new or rotated DEKs.

By encrypting fields client-side and managing keys exclusively in Cloud KMS, you protect sensitive Firestore data from server-side compromise and satisfy compliance for data-in-transit and at-rest confidentiality.

References

  • Server-side encryption

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement query limits and pagination in your application logic and configure budget alerts in Google Cloud Billing to detect abnormal costs
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent runaway reads (and unexpected bills) by enforcing strict query size caps in your application code and by configuring Cloud Billing budgets to alert on anomalous spend:

  1. Implement query limits & pagination
    • In your client or backend, never issue unbounded CollectionReference.get() calls.
    • Use Firestores limit(n) and startAfter() (or cursor) methods to page through results in fixedsize batches (for example, 100 documents at a time).
    • Combine with indexed queries and orderBy() on a clustered field (timestamp or ID) to ensure consistent performance and avoid full-collection scans.
    • On the UI side, present Next/Previous controls instead of loading thousands of records in one go.
  2. Failsafe on exceeded thresholds
    • Wrap query execution in a guard that aborts (and logs an error) if the requested page number or cumulative reads exceeds a configured maximum (for example, no more than 1,000 document reads per user request).
    • Return HTTP 413 (Request Too Large) or a custom error code when limits are hit, rather than degrading performance or incurring extra reads.
  3. Configure Billing budget alerts
    • In Cloud Console Billing Budgets & alerts, create a Budget scoped to your Firestore project with a threshold at, say, 50% of your expected monthly spend.
    • Enable notifications to email, Pub/Sub topic, or Slack via Cloud Functions when thresholds (50%, 80%, 100%) are crossed.
    • For more fine-grained monitoring, attach a billing export to BigQuery and write a scheduled query that alerts on daily Firestore read-operation spikes.
  4. Continuous tuning & review
    • Instrument metrics on Firestore document reads per request in Cloud Monitoring; create an alert for sudden spikes or patterns of pagination abuse.
    • Quarterly, review budget actual vs. forecast spend and adjust query limits or UI behaviors to balance user needs and cost control.

By bounding your Firestore reads in code and pairing it with proactive budget alerts, you protect both performance and your wallet from excessive or malicious data-access patterns.

References

  • Create, edit, or delete budgets and budget alerts

countermeasure.name: Use Firestore Security Rules on the server-side to validate data structure, content, and user permissions before any write operation
countermeasure.desc:
Define and deploy robust Firestore Security Rules so that every client-side write is checked on the backend for schema, content validity, and user authorization before the data is persisted:

  1. Enforce document structure
    • In your firestore.rules file, declare a strict schema for each collection, e.g.:
      • match /orders/{orderId} {
         allow create: if request.resource.data.keys().hasAll(['userId','items','total']) 
                       && request.resource.data.items is list 
                       && request.resource.data.total is number;
        }
    • Reject writes missing required fields, wrong data types, or extra unexpected keys.
  2. Sanitize and bound content
    • Add value checks to prevent injection or abusive data, for example:
      • // items array size limit and total non-negative
        request.resource.data.items.size() <= 100
        && request.resource.data.total >= 0;
    • Use regex to validate string formats (email, IDs) and limit lengths (.size() <= 256).
  3. Verify user permissions
    • Tie writes to the authenticated users UID, e.g.:
      • allow update, delete: if request.auth.uid == resource.data.userId;
        allow read: if request.auth.uid != null;
    • Ensure users cannot modify or delete other users documents.
  4. Test rules with the Emulator & CI
    • Run firebase emulators:exec or use the Firestore Emulator SDK in your CI pipeline to simulate read/write requests against your rules.
    • Fail the build if any unauthorized or malformed access is permitted.
  5. Audit and iterate
    • Deploy rules_version = '2' and enable logging (debug() calls) to surface denied writes in Cloud Logging for further tuning.
    • Review rule coverage after each new feature, and run automated rulecoverage metrics to detect gaps.

By validating structure, content, and auth entirely within Firestore Security Rules, you prevent malformed or unauthorized writes without relying on client codeensuring a secure, consistent data layer.

References

  • Writing conditions for Cloud Firestore Security Rules

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Use VPC Service Controls to create a service perimeter that prevents data from leaving your trusted network
countermeasure.desc:
Define a VPC Service Controls perimeter around the Google Cloud projects that host your Firestore databases so that any attempt to read or write documents from outside your trusted network is automatically blocked.

  1. Create an access policy
    • In the Cloud Console, go to Security VPC Service Controls Access Policies and Create Policy.
  2. Define the perimeter
    • Within that policy, Add Perimeter, select Regular perimeter, and include only the projects containing your Firestore instances.
    • Under Services, add firestore.googleapis.com, and any other GCP services (Storage, BigQuery) your Firestore workflows legitimately call.
  3. Configure ingress and egress rules
    • Egress: block all calls from inside the perimeter to external networks, except explicit APIs you allow (for example, to your on-prem monitoring systems via Private Service Connect).
    • Ingress: allow management from approved IP ranges by creating an Access Level (e.g., corporate VPN CIDRs) under Identity & Access Management Access Context Manager and attaching it as an ingress exception.
  4. Test the perimeter
    • From a VM or client outside your VPN, attempt to execute a Firestore read or write (gcloud firestore documents list )requests should fail with a PERIMETER_VIOLATION error.
    • From within the allowed network or via Private Service Connect, confirm normal Firestore operations succeed.
  5. Monitor and maintain
    • Turn on Access Logs for VPC-SC to capture any PERIMETER_VIOLATION events and forward them to Cloud Logging.
    • Quarterly, review the list of projects and services in the perimeter to ensure no drift; update when you onboard new environments or retire old ones.

Enforcing a VPC Service Controls perimeter ensures that even if credentials are compromised, Firestore data cannot be exfiltrated outside your defined security boundary.

References

  • Overview of VPC Service Controls
  • Service perimeter details and configuration

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of Service (DoS) due to excessive reads/writes
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

An attacker can intentionally trigger a massive number of read or write operations against the Firestore database. This exhausts service quotas, leading to significant financial costs and making the database unresponsive to legitimate user traffic. Poorly configured security rules or inefficient query patterns can exacerbate this vulnerability.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious external actors, disgruntled insiders, or automated botnets.
  • Vectors: Exploiting overly permissive security rules (allow read, write: if true;), executing resource-intensive queries from a compromised client, or using scripts to rapidly create or delete a high volume of documents.

Impacts

  • Service unavailability for legitimate users, degrading application performance.
  • Substantial and unexpected financial bills due to pay-as-you-go pricing for operations.
  • Potential for data loss or corruption if the attack involves malicious write or delete operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A malicious script exploits a publicly writable collection to continuously create new documents, rapidly exceeding the daily write quota and incurring high costs.
  • An attacker identifies an inefficient query that scans a large number of documents and repeatedly triggers it from multiple clients, consuming the read quota and slowing down the database for all users.
  • A compromised front-end application with broad permissions is used to recursively delete documents in a critical collection, causing a denial of service for features that rely on that data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insecure service account management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly managed service account keys or roles can grant unintended access to the Firestore database. An attacker who compromises a service account with overly permissive IAM roles can bypass Firestore Security Rules, leading to data exfiltration, manipulation, or destruction. This is especially critical for service accounts used in CI/CD pipelines, VMs, or other backend services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party services.
  • Vectors: Leaked service account JSON keys (e.g., committed to a public code repository), assigning primitive roles like Owner or Editor instead of granular Firestore roles, or exploiting a compromised resource (like a GCE VM) that has a privileged service account attached.

Impacts

  • Complete bypass of Firestore Security Rules, allowing unauthorized read/write access to any part of the database.
  • Data exfiltration of sensitive information stored in Firestore collections.
  • Privilege escalation within the GCP project if the service account has permissions beyond just Firestore.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker finds a service account key hardcoded in a public GitHub repository, uses it to authenticate as the service, and proceeds to download all user data from the Firestore database.
  • A developer attaches a service account with the Project Editor role to a Compute Engine instance for simplicity. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the application running on the VM, gains access to the attached service account's token, and uses it to delete critical Firestore collections.
  • A former employee's service account, which was used for a script and had extensive access, is never disabled. The ex-employee uses the still-valid key to maliciously alter data in the database.

threat.name: Lack of auditing and monitoring for access control changes
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Failure to monitor changes to Firestore Security Rules or IAM policies allows attackers to modify access controls undetected. This creates a critical blind spot, enabling persistent, unauthorized access for data theft or manipulation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders or external attackers using compromised privileged accounts.
  • Vectors: Directly modifying Firestore Security Rules to be permissive or assigning high-privilege IAM roles (roles/datastore.owner) to unauthorized accounts.

Impacts

  • Long-term, undetected data breaches and exfiltration.
  • Inability to conduct forensic analysis to determine the scope of an incident.
  • Compliance failures due to a lack of mandatory access control auditing.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker compromises an admin account, opens up a security rule for a sensitive collection, and steals the data. The change goes unnoticed.
  • An insider grants their personal account a Firebase Rules Admin role, alters rules to steal data, and reverts the change without raising any alerts.
  • A compromised CI/CD pipeline deploys a permissive firestore.rules file, exposing the database without the security team's knowledge.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Firestore data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This is a foundational threat where users gain access to data that they are not authorized to see or modify. It is typically caused by poorly written or incomplete Firestore Security Rules, which fail to properly enforce the application's access control logic. An attacker can exploit these flaws from the client-side (web/mobile app) to read, alter, or delete data.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Any authenticated or unauthenticated end-user of the application.
  • Vectors: Logic flaws in security rules (e.g., allowing updates without validating all fields), missing rules for new data collections, or rules that fail to properly check the user's identity (request.auth.uid) against the resource being accessed.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality breach from unauthorized reads of sensitive data.
  • Integrity loss from unauthorized modification or creation of data.
  • Service unavailability if an attacker deletes critical data that other users rely on.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A security rule allows a user to update their profile (allow update: if request.auth.uid == userId;), but doesn't prevent them from changing a role field. A regular user updates their own profile to set role: 'admin', escalating their privileges.
  • A developer adds a new internal_logs collection but forgets to write a security rule for it. Since there is no rule, access may be denied, or worse, allowed if default rules are permissive, exposing internal data.
  • A rule to create a document correctly checks the incoming user ID, but the rule for updating it is missing or too permissive, allowing any user to overwrite another user's document later on.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Data exfiltration over public endpoints
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Firestore is accessed via public-facing REST and RPC APIs, making it susceptible to data exfiltration if not properly secured. Misconfigured Security Rules or overly permissive IAM policies can allow an attacker to directly query and download sensitive data from the database over the internet without ever needing to compromise a server.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious web scrapers, or any authenticated/unauthenticated user.
  • Vectors: Exploiting overly broad Security Rules (e.g., allow read: if true;), leaving collections publicly readable by default, or compromising a user account or client-side token that has wide read access.

Impacts

  • Loss of confidentiality and exfiltration of sensitive user data, PII, or company secrets.
  • Reputational damage and loss of customer trust.
  • Regulatory fines and legal action for failing to protect data as required by laws like GDPR or CCPA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker discovers a users collection is publicly readable. They write a simple script to iterate through the collection and download every user's profile information.
  • A mobile application's traffic is analyzed, revealing that Firestore queries are not properly restricted. An attacker uses the API endpoint directly to run their own queries, accessing data meant for other users.
  • A misconfigured rule allow read: if request.auth != null; is intended to protect data, but the application has an easy-to-abuse public sign-up feature. An attacker creates an account and gains read access to all data protected by that rule.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in plaintext
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Storing sensitive information (e.g., passwords, API keys, personal identifiable information) as plaintext in Firestore documents means that anyone who gains read access to the data can immediately use it. This bypasses any need for further decryption or complex exploitation. A single security misconfiguration can lead to a direct, high-impact data breach.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or even developers during debugging.
  • Vectors: Exploiting overly permissive Security Rules, compromising a service account with read permissions, or accidental exposure through database backups or exports.

Impacts

  • Immediate compromise of user credentials, PII, financial data, or system secrets.
  • Severe regulatory penalties (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) for failing to protect sensitive data.
  • Attackers can use leaked credentials or API keys to escalate their privileges and move laterally across other systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker finds a publicly readable collection due to a rule misconfiguration and downloads user documents containing plaintext email addresses and phone numbers.
  • A disgruntled employee with read access to the production database exports a collection containing sensitive API keys for third-party services, which were stored in a configuration document.
  • A developer accidentally logs a full document during error handling, exposing a user's plaintext password in the application logs, which are later compromised.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.001 - Credentials In Files

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure client-side data validation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Relying solely on client-side code (e.g., JavaScript in a browser or Swift/Kotlin in a mobile app) for data validation is insecure. Attackers can easily bypass these front-end checks and interact directly with the Firestore API. Without server-side validation enforced by Security Rules, they can write malformed, unauthorized, or malicious data directly into the database.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious users, automated scripts, or anyone with knowledge of the API endpoint.
  • Vectors: Using browser developer tools to modify network requests, writing a custom script to call the Firestore REST API, or reverse-engineering a mobile app to send arbitrary data.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity Loss: Invalid data (e.g., negative product prices, empty required fields, incorrect data types) is saved to the database, corrupting application state.
  • Application Logic Failure: The application may crash or behave unpredictably when it encounters data that violates its core assumptions about structure and values.
  • Security Vulnerabilities: Storing un-sanitized data can lead to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) if the data is later rendered in a web client, or it can be used to exploit logic flaws in backend systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A shopping cart's front-end logic ensures an order quantity is between 1 and 5. An attacker bypasses this by sending a direct API call to Firestore, setting the quantity to -100 to trigger a refund or 1000 to abuse a promotion.
  • A user profile form validates that a username field is a string of 20 characters or less. An attacker sends a direct request with a 2000-character username containing a malicious script payload, which could break the UI or execute in other users' browsers.
  • The application client ensures a role field in a user document can only be "viewer". An attacker bypasses the client and writes "editor" directly to the database, potentially escalating their privileges if other parts of the system use that field for authorization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-223
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-223: Omission of Security-relevant Information The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Block all inbound port traffic from 0.0.0.0/0
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Load Balancing setup, it is critical to implement network security rules that block all inbound traffic from untrusted sources. This is essential in minimizing exposure to potential attacks. Follow these steps to configure your network security rules effectively:

  1. Identify the untrusted sources: Determine which IP ranges are considered untrusted (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0). The default 0.0.0.0/0 represents all IPv4 addresses, and you should explicitly specify trusted sources to ensure only these can access your load balancer.

  2. Access the Google Cloud Console: Navigate to the Firewall rules page in your GCP console.

  3. Create or update firewall rules:

    • Select or create a rule to enforce that inbound traffic from the untrusted source range(s) is disallowed. You can edit existing rules or add new firewall rules as necessary.
    • Ensure your firewall rules are applied to the VMs behind your load balancer by specifying the appropriate network tags or service accounts.

  4. Configure your load balancer:

    • Ensure that the backend service of your load balancer is configured to only accept traffic that passes through the firewall rules. This can be done by associating the backend with secured networks and limiting access only to approved sources.
    • For HTTP(S) load balancing, enable the use of HTTPS traffic management features to further enhance security by requiring secure connections.

  5. Test the configuration: Regularly monitor and test your network security rules to ensure that your configuration effectively blocks inappropriate access and only allows access from trusted sources.

For more detailed information on setting up and maintaining secure load balancing configurations, refer to the GCP Load Balancing Best Practices. This document provides extensive guidance on secure configurations and management of Google Cloud Load Balancing.

countermeasure.name: Configure load balancing with zonal NEGs
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure high availability and improved performance in your application deployments on Google Cloud Platform (GCP), it is recommended to use zonal Network Endpoint Groups (NEGs) for distributing traffic efficiently across different zones. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Understand Zonal NEGs: Zonal NEGs represent groups of service endpoints in specific zones. Utilizing them allows your load balancer to send traffic to instances in the healthiest zones, thereby enhancing reliability and availability.
  2. Create Zonal NEGs: Configure zonal NEGs for your VM instances or services within the specified zones. This ensures that traffic is efficiently directed to appropriate active endpoints in each zone.
  3. Integrate with Load Balancer: After configuring zonal NEGs, integrate them with your HTTP(S) Load Balancer. This ensures that requests are routed based on proximity and health, leveraging Google's global network effectively. The HTTP(S) Load Balancer setup guide provides step-by-step instructions for this configuration.
  4. Monitor and Adjust: Once integrated, continuously monitor the traffic distribution and instances' health status across zones. Use GCP's monitoring tools to adjust NEG configurations for optimal performance and to address any potential bottlenecks. More information can be found in the Cloud Monitoring documentation.

Implementing zonal NEGs helps maintain a resilient and performant architecture by providing geographically distributed endpoints for handling application loads. For additional security and best practices, refer to the overall HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices document.

countermeasure.name: Control access and ensure Least Privilege to Cloud Load Balancing
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to Cloud Load Balancing services, implement IAM access control and apply the principle of least privilege. Begin by identifying the specific roles and permissions required for users interacting with Cloud Load Balancing. Assign these roles using the IAM & Admin section in the Google Cloud Console, ensuring that users and service accounts have only the permissions essential for their functions.

Consult the official Google Cloud IAM documentation to understand predefined roles that could be used to restrict access effectively. Use custom IAM roles if predefined roles do not meet your organization's specific needs.
Be cautious when granting the roles like roles/owner or roles/editor, as they provide broad access to resources.

Regularly review IAM policies by setting up audits and monitoring using IAM audit logs to identify potential over-privileged access. Periodically adjust permissions to align with current job responsibilities and security policies, removing unnecessary rights from users who no longer require them.

Incorporate the best practice guidelines from the Load Balancing Best Practices document to ensure robust security postures for load balancing activities. Regularly update your knowledge and practices according to the most current recommendations provided by Google Cloud.

countermeasure.name: Enable connection draining on Load Balancers
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the graceful completion of ongoing requests during maintenance or shutdown of backend instances in GCP Load Balancing, you should configure connection draining. Connection draining allows existing connections to finish processing before the instance is terminated, thus preventing disruption in service and improving reliability.

Here is a step-by-step guidance on implementing connection draining:

  1. Access Google Cloud Console: Sign in to your Google Cloud Console.

  2. Navigate to Load Balancing: In the console, select Network services and then Load balancing.

  3. Choose the Load Balancer: Locate the load balancer you wish to modify by selecting it from the available list.

  4. Edit Backend Service: Under the selected load balancer, navigate to the Backend configuration tab and click on the backend service that you want to set up connection draining for.

  5. Configure Connection Draining: In the backend service settings, set the desired connection draining timeout value, which defines how long the load balancer will wait for current connections to end before forcefully closing them. Ensure this timeout period aligns with your application's expected request duration for optimal results.

  6. Save and Apply Changes: After setting the connection draining timeout, save your changes and allow the load balancer to refresh its configuration.

For further details and the most updated procedures on configuring connection draining within GCP Load Balancing, please refer to the official documentation available at GCP Connection Draining.

countermeasure.name: Enable logging of load balancing health checks
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility into the performance and status of your Cloud Load Balancers, it is essential to enable logging for health checks. This measure will allow you to monitor the operational health of backend services and promptly detect any issues.

To implement logging for health checks in Google Cloud Load Balancing, follow these steps:

  1. Enable Google Cloud Logging: Begin by ensuring that Google Cloud Logging is enabled for your Google Cloud project. This service will aggregate log data, including health check logs, for analysis and monitoring. More details can be found in the Google Cloud Logging documentation.
  2. Configure Logging in Load Balancer: Navigate to your load balancer settings in the Google Cloud Console. For HTTP(S) Load Balancers, set up or edit your existing load balancer and proceed to enable logging under the backend services or backend buckets. Refer to the step-by-step guide on configuring a load balancer for assistance.
  3. Verify and Specify Logging Parameters: Once logging is activated, verify that the appropriate log types are being captured. Typically, you should log both successful and failed health checks to obtain a comprehensive view of your load balancer's performance.
  4. Monitor and Review Logs: Utilize Google Cloud's operations suite to actively monitor and review health check logs. This will help you identify trends, troubleshoot issues, and ensure optimal performance.

By carefully enabling and configuring logging for health checks, you can improve security, optimize performance, and ensure the reliability of your Cloud Load Balancers.

countermeasure.name: Securely store your credentials and rotate Google Service account keys
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your GCP Load Balancing setup, it's imperative to manage and protect sensitive credentials such as service account keys effectively. Using Google Cloud's Secret Manager simplifies the storage and management of these secrets securely. Here are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Store Service Account Keys Securely:
    • Navigate to the Google Cloud Console and access the Secret Manager service.
    • Create a new secret to store your Google service account key. Upload the JSON key file and configure versioning if needed.
    • Restrict access to the secret by setting appropriate IAM policies, allowing only necessary users and services access.
  2. Configure Automatic Rotation:
    • Set up secret rotation by following the guidelines outlined in Managing Secrets documentation.
    • Enable the automatic rotation feature by specifying a rotation schedule, ensuring that secrets are rotated periodically to minimize exposure risks.
  3. Update Load Balancing Configuration:
    • Ensure that your load balancing configuration references service account keys securely stored in Secret Manager.
    • Reload or refresh configurations to apply new key versions after rotation, thus maintaining uninterrupted secure operations.

Implementing these measures enhances the security posture of your Google Cloud Platform services by reducing the attack surface associated with exposed credentials. For further details, refer to the HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices.

countermeasure.name: Use Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and control access to your applications behind Google Cloud Load Balancers, implement Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP). IAP provides secure, perimeter-less access control to your web applications hosted on Google Cloud, ensuring that only authenticated and authorized users can access your services.

Step-by-Step Guidance for Cloud Engineers:

  1. Enable IAP API: Begin by enabling the Identity-Aware Proxy API in your Google Cloud Platform project. This can be done via the GCP Console or using the command line.
    • Console: Navigate to APIs & Services > Library and enable the IAP API.
    • Command Line: Use the following command: 
      gcloud services enable iap.googleapis.com
  2. Configure OAuth consent screen: Set up your OAuth consent screen to declare what resources your application will access and who can use it. This is required to use IAP as it relies on OAuth 2.0.
    • Navigate to API & Services > Credentials > OAuth consent screen. Configure the necessary information like application name, support email, and authorized domains.
  3. Define IAP-secured Resources: Identify the load balancers and the associated backend services you wish to secure with IAP. Ensure all requests to these resources are routed through the IAP.
  4. Configure Backend Services for IAP: Ensure your backend service is compatible with IAP. This requires using HTTPS for communication with the backend.
  5. Set up Access Controls: Define access policies to manage which user and group accounts can access your applications via IAP. Use IAM roles to grant permissions appropriately. Test Configuration: After setting up IAP, thoroughly test it to ensure that the authentication and authorization mechanisms are functioning as expected. Attempt to access the application both with and without the required permissions to verify that access controls are correctly enforced.

By implementing Identity-Aware Proxy with your GCP Load Balancers, you add an extra layer of security by enforcing application-level security policies without relying on a traditional perimeter-based network security model.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unmonitored load balancing health status
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of visibility into the health of Load Balancers can lead to undetected failures or vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include unauthorized users or attackers who exploit the lack of monitoring and visibility in order to introduce vulnerabilities, causing failures or performance issues that go unnoticed.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat can include failure to detect and resolve issues promptly, potentially leading to degraded performance, increased downtime, and susceptibility to attacks or exploits that could have been prevented with proper monitoring.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example involves an attacker exploiting a vulnerability that goes unnoticed due to insufficient health monitoring, allowing them to cause a denial of service attack by overloading the server resources, leaving legitimate users unable to access services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

threat.name: Unrestricted network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Allowing inbound traffic from all sources can significantly expose your system to a variety of attacks, leading to potential security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors who take advantage of unrestricted access to attempt unauthorized entry or launch DDoS attacks.
Impacts
Potential impacts include service disruption, unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exhaustion, and increased vulnerability to DDoS attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by flooding the network with illegitimate traffic, causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Alternatively, a hacker might gain unauthorized access to internal systems by exploiting open ports.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Service fisruption furing Load Balancer maintenance
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of proper draining configurations during load balancer maintenance can result in abrupt terminations of active connections. This can affect service availability and lead to interrupted user sessions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include system administrators who fail to configure connection draining settings, as well as automated systems or scripts executing maintenance tasks without adequately managing active connections.
Impacts
The impact includes potential disruption of online services, loss of user data in transit, and negative user experience. This can further result in loss of revenue and damage to service reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator schedules routine maintenance on the load balancer without enabling connection draining. As a result, active sessions are dropped abruptly, leading to loss of user activity data and complaints from users of interrupted services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Inefficient load distribution across zones
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor configuration of Load Balancers can result in unequal resource allocation across various zones, which may negatively impact performance and availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or system administrators who lack knowledge or make errors in the configuration of load balancers.
Impacts
This can lead to significant performance degradation and potential downtime, affecting user experience and business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A security administrator erroneously configures a load balancer to route all traffic to a single zone, overwhelming it and causing service delays or outages.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Cloud Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control may allow unauthorized users to configure or misuse Cloud Load Balancing, leading to potential disruptions or attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users exploiting misconfigured access controls to gain access to Cloud Load Balancing settings.
Impacts
Potential disruptions, data breaches, or service unavailability due to unauthorized configuration changes or misuse.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a poorly configured load balancer and reroutes traffic, causing an outage or redirects users to a malicious site.

threat.name: Compromised credentials and key management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to properly secure credentials and rotate keys increases the risk of unauthorized access, potentially leading to security breaches in cloud infrastructure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or insiders who gain access to unsecured or outdated credentials can exploit this vulnerability to infiltrate cloud resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and disruption of services, ultimately damaging the organization's reputation and causing financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers static credentials hardcoded in an application and uses them to access sensitive cloud resources. Additionally, a former employee uses unexpired credentials to access critical systems, leading to data exfiltration.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to applications behind load balancers
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control can lead to unauthorized access to backend applications through load balancing, potentially exposing sensitive data and compromising application integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious users or insiders may exploit misconfigurations in access control settings of the load balancer to gain unauthorized access to backend systems.
Impacts
Unauthorized access may result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and diminished trust in system security.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers and exploits a misconfigured load balancer rule that lacks proper access control restrictions, allowing them to directly interact with critical backend systems without authentication.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

countermeasure.name: Automatically apply security patches to SQLServer instances
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize the risk of security vulnerabilities, configure SQLServer instances in GCP to automatically receive and apply security patches. Keeping SQLServer instances up to date with the latest security patches is essential in addressing newly discovered vulnerabilities and protecting your data from potential exploits. Automatic patching reduces the need for manual intervention and ensures that critical updates are applied promptly, helping to maintain a secure environment.

In GCP, you can enable automatic patching for your SQLServer instances through the Google Cloud Console or by configuring patch management policies. Regular patching reduces the attack surface by addressing known vulnerabilities, making your SQLServer instances less susceptible to attacks. Additionally, monitoring patching schedules and verifying the successful application of patches should be part of your routine security operations to ensure continuous protection.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL Maintenance for SQL Server

countermeasure.name: Enable Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) for SQLServer data and logs
countermeasure.desc:
Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) is a security feature that automatically encrypts SQLServer data files and logs at rest, ensuring the protection of sensitive information stored in your SQLServer instances. By enabling TDE, all data written to disk is encrypted, including database backups and transaction logs, which helps to prevent unauthorized access to data through physical storage theft or breaches. TDE also provides automatic encryption without requiring changes to applications, simplifying the implementation process.

In GCP, encryption at rest is automatically managed for SQLServer instances to safeguard your data and maintain compliance with data protection regulations. This ensures that sensitive data remains encrypted at all times, reducing the risk of exposure in case of security incidents. You can enhance security by using customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) to maintain control over the encryption process. Regularly auditing encryption status and key usage will help ensure the ongoing security of your data at rest.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Google Cloud Encryption at Rest

countermeasure.name: Encrypt SQLServer backups to secure backup and restore processes
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all SQLServer backups are encrypted to protect data during both backup and restore procedures. Unencrypted backups are vulnerable to unauthorized access, especially when stored or transferred. By applying encryption to SQLServer backups, sensitive data is safeguarded against potential threats, ensuring that even if the backup files are intercepted or improperly accessed, the data remains protected and unreadable.

In GCP, SQLServer backups can be automatically encrypted using various encryption options, such as customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) or Google-managed encryption keys. Implementing encryption for backups should be part of your broader data protection strategy, ensuring that the security of your SQLServer data extends beyond its operational environment.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Cloud SQL - Backup and Restore
  • Google Cloud Encryption at Rest

reference.name: 6.7 - Ensure That Cloud SQL Database Instances Are Configured With Automated Backups

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Integrate SQL Server with Google Cloud IAM for identity and access management
countermeasure.desc:
Integrating Cloud SQL for SQL Server instances with Google Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) allows for centralized and secure management of access to your SQL Server instances. By leveraging IAM, you can assign fine-grained permissions to specific users, groups, or service accounts, ensuring that only authorized personnel can interact with your SQL Server resources. This integration helps enforce the principle of least privilege, where each user or service is given only the minimum level of access required to perform their job functions.

Additionally, Google Cloud IAM provides role-based access controls (RBAC) and policies that allow you to define precise access controls based on job functions, ensuring compliance with security policies and regulatory requirements. The integration also facilitates comprehensive logging of access and modification events, which is essential for audit trails and compliance checks. Regularly reviewing these access logs will help you identify potential security risks or unauthorized attempts to access sensitive data stored in SQL Server instances. Implementing IAM integration reduces the risk of credential misuse and strengthens your overall security posture.

References:

  • Google Cloud SQL for SQL Server Documentation
  • Google Cloud IAM Overview

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data transmitted without encryption is vulnerable to interception by unauthorized parties, leading to data breaches or exposure of sensitive information. Without proper encryption mechanisms, attackers can easily intercept data in transit and gain unauthorized access.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include attackers intercepting network traffic (man-in-the-middle attacks), malicious insiders, or compromised network infrastructure that allows unauthorized monitoring of data exchanges.

Impacts
Sensitive data, such as credentials, personal identifiable information (PII), or financial data, could be exposed during transmission, resulting in data breaches, legal liabilities, and financial losses.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker captures unencrypted SQL queries transmitted between the application and the SQLServer, exposing sensitive data such as credit card numbers or authentication credentials.
  2. During a database replication process, unencrypted data is intercepted, leading to the leak of customer data to a malicious third party.
  3. An insider monitors unencrypted traffic within the organizations network and retrieves sensitive information from ongoing communications between services and SQLServer databases.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Insecure backup and restore procedures
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate backup and restore procedures can lead to unauthorized access, data loss, or data integrity issues. If backups are not properly encrypted or access to backup files is not restricted, sensitive data may be exposed or compromised during the backup and restoration process.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers, malicious insiders, or unauthorized personnel could gain access to unprotected backups, potentially restoring sensitive data or manipulating backup files to introduce vulnerabilities or alter data integrity.

Impacts
Unsecured backups could lead to unauthorized data access, leakage of sensitive information, or loss of critical data. This could severely impact business operations, legal compliance, and data recovery efforts in the event of system failures.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A backup file stored on an unencrypted disk is accessed by an attacker, exposing sensitive customer data.
  2. A malicious insider with access to backup data manipulates the backup files, restoring a compromised version of the database to alter financial records.
  3. An attacker intercepts the backup process and introduces malware into the backup files, compromising the integrity of restored data during disaster recovery procedures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1543 - Create or Modify System Process

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Weak or insufficient authentication mechanisms can allow unauthorized access to GCP SQLServer instances. Without strong authentication, attackers may exploit vulnerabilities to gain access to sensitive databases, potentially leading to data theft, modification, or disruption of services.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers could exploit weak passwords, unprotected access keys, or insecure authentication protocols. Insider threats may arise if employees or contractors are given inappropriate or excessive privileges.

Impacts
Compromised authentication controls can result in unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or service downtime. Sensitive information may be leaked, leading to reputational damage and regulatory penalties.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker uses brute force to guess weak passwords and gains access to the SQLServer database, exfiltrating sensitive customer data.
  2. An insider with excessive access rights manipulates critical data in the SQLServer without being properly authenticated or tracked.
  3. Inadequately secured service accounts are exploited by external actors, allowing unauthorized access to the SQLServer infrastructure.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerability in SQLServer patches
threat.desc:
General threat description
Vulnerabilities in outdated or unpatched SQLServer software can expose the system to potential exploits. Attackers can take advantage of these vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt database services, compromising the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of data stored in SQLServer instances.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, malware, or malicious insiders who exploit known vulnerabilities in unpatched SQLServer instances. Attack vectors include SQL injection attacks, privilege escalation, or remote code execution through unpatched software.

Impacts
Exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities could lead to data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive information, or full control over the SQLServer environment. This could result in data loss, financial damage, and reputational harm to organizations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker identifies an SQLServer instance running an outdated version with a known vulnerability. Using remote code execution, the attacker gains unauthorized access to the system.
  2. A malicious actor exploits a SQLServer vulnerability to escalate privileges within the environment, gaining access to administrative functions and sensitive data.
  3. Attackers use automated tools to scan for unpatched SQLServer instances on the internet, exploiting them to deploy ransomware or steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

weakness.name: CWE-1007
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1007: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply Bucket Lock policies to enforce retention periods for stored objects
countermeasure.desc:
Apply Bucket Lock policies in GCP Storage to enforce mandatory retention periods on objects within storage buckets. This prevents any deletion or modification of data during the specified retention period. This security control is essential for protecting critical data from accidental deletions, overwrites, or unauthorized changes. Once configured, the retention period cannot be shortened or removed, offering robust protection for sensitive data that must comply with regulatory or legal retention requirements. Bucket Lock can also be combined with object holds to protect individual objects beyond the retention settings.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Bucket Lock Documentation

countermeasure.name: Configure signed URLs to provide time-limited access to storage objects
countermeasure.desc:
Configure signed URLs in GCP Storage to allow time-limited access to specific objects without exposing the entire bucket. Signed URLs provide a secure mechanism to grant temporary access to an object for a defined period, after which the URL expires and access is revoked. This is particularly useful for scenarios where you need to share objects with external users or systems in a controlled manner. By using signed URLs, you ensure that access to sensitive objects is restricted, protecting the storage bucket while still enabling authorized users to retrieve the needed files within a specified time frame.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Signed URLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable object versioning in GCP Storage buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Enable object versioning in GCP Storage to automatically retain prior versions of objects stored in buckets. This feature ensures that whenever an object is modified, deleted, or overwritten, the previous versions remain accessible for recovery. Object versioning is an essential safeguard against accidental deletions or modifications, allowing you to restore earlier versions of files when necessary. This feature is particularly useful in environments where multiple users or automated processes interact with the same objects, reducing the risk of permanent data loss due to human error or unexpected overwrites.

When object versioning is enabled, GCP Storage keeps track of object changes by assigning unique version identifiers to each version of an object. You can access, restore, or even delete specific object versions as needed. This can be configured at the bucket level, and its important to consider implementing version lifecycle management to control the storage cost of maintaining old versions by automatically deleting older versions based on your organizations data retention policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Object Versioning Documentation

countermeasure.name: Use fine-grained access control for object-level permissions in GCP Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage fine-grained access control to enforce more precise, object-level permissions within GCP Storage. Unlike bucket-level permissions, fine-grained control allows you to assign specific roles and access permissions directly to individual storage objects. This ensures that users and services only have the minimum required access to specific data, greatly reducing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, or unintentional modifications. This is particularly useful for environments where different users or services need varying levels of access to objects within the same bucket. For instance, one user might need read access to a subset of objects, while another might require write permissions to other objects. By applying object-level roles, you can tailor security settings to align with your organizations data protection policies, improving overall security and compliance.

Additionally, fine-grained access control integrates with Google Cloud IAM, allowing you to define roles and assign them based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users and services can only interact with data that they are authorized to access. It is also advisable to regularly review and audit permissions to ensure that access remains appropriate over time and does not violate security policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Fine-Grained Access Control Documentation

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A companys storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-662
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-662: Improper Synchronization The product utilizes multiple threads or processes to allow temporary access to a shared resource that can only be exclusive to one process at a time, but it does not properly synchronize these actions, which might cause simultaneous accesses of this resource by multiple threads or processes.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Assign IAM roles to restrict task management
countermeasure.desc:
Assign specific IAM roles to control who can create, run, and manage tasks within GCP Tasks, ensuring that only authorized users or services have the necessary permissions. This control enforces the principle of least privilege by granting only the required permissions needed for specific roles, which minimizes the attack surface and reduces the risk of unauthorized actions. To implement this control, review the roles and permissions available within Google Cloud IAM and assign them based on job functions. Regularly audit and review IAM policies to ensure permissions remain aligned with organizational policies and security needs. By doing so, you mitigate the risk of unauthorized users creating, modifying, or running tasks, which could lead to security incidents or operational disruptions. Additionally, consider implementing automated alerts and monitoring for unusual activity related to task management.

References:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation

countermeasure.name: Configure rate limiting and retry policies for task execution
countermeasure.desc:
Configure rate limiting and retry policies for GCP Tasks to control the number of tasks executed in a given time frame and prevent excessive retries. This ensures system stability by avoiding overloading your application with excessive task requests, which could lead to performance degradation or service outages. By setting appropriate retry policies, you can ensure that failed tasks are retried in a controlled manner, without overwhelming the system with excessive retries. This control also helps in managing and optimizing costs by preventing unnecessary resource consumption caused by runaway retries or task overload. It is essential to periodically review and adjust these policies based on system performance and operational requirements to strike the right balance between fault tolerance and resource efficiency.

References:

  • GCP Tasks Retry Configuration

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Implement access control at the task queue level
countermeasure.desc:
To secure GCP Tasks, implement access control at the task queue level to prevent unauthorized access. By restricting who can access, create, or modify tasks within specific queues, you ensure that only trusted services or authorized users can interact with sensitive tasks or data. Use IAM roles to grant specific permissions based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring users and services only have access to the resources they need. Regularly audit access control settings to ensure that permissions are aligned with organizational policies, and remove any unnecessary access to reduce the attack surface.

References:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Use task leasing to prevent duplicate task processing
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that tasks are processed efficiently and without duplication, implement task leasing mechanisms in GCP Tasks. By leasing tasks, you can guarantee that only one worker processes a task at a time, preventing race conditions or duplicate processing. This approach assigns a time-limited "lease" to each worker for a task, and other workers will not be able to process the same task during this lease period. If the task fails or is not completed within the lease time, it becomes available for reprocessing. This mechanism enhances reliability and ensures consistent task execution in distributed systems.

References:

  • GCP Tasks Documentation
